sub_topic: Prove that the power set of a set is always larger than the set itself.
message_1: Let X = {1,2,3}. Calculate the cardinality of the power set of X (i.e., the number of subsets of X), and compare it with the cardinality of X itself. Show that the power set of X has strictly more elements than X.
message_2:
Let X = {1,2,3}. The power set of X, denoted as P(X), is the set of all possible subsets of X, including the empty set and X itself. To find the cardinality of the power set of X, we can list all the subsets:

P(X) = {âˆ…, {1}, {2}, {3}, {1,2}, {1,3}, {2,3}, {1,2,3}}

There are 8 subsets in P(X), so the cardinality of P(X) is 8.

Now let's compare the cardinality of P(X) with the cardinality of X itself. The cardinality of X is the number of elements in X, which is 3 (since X = {1,2,3}).

Since the cardinality of P(X) is 8 and the cardinality of X is 3, we can see that the power set of X has strictly more elements than X (8 > 3).
